Headline

Gravity Re-engagement Causes Minor Spillage in Sector 7G; Jazz Trio Unfazed

A sudden, scheduled gravity re-engagement aboard Claw & Cloud Flight 901 to Europa resulted in approximately 3.8 liters of spilled gin and tonic. The ship's resident jazz trio, "The Cool Cats," reportedly didn't miss a beat during their rendition of 'Take Five'.

"The gin was a tragedy, of course," said passenger Amelia Earhart (no relation). "But the drummer's hi-hat work during the zero-to-one-g transition was simply sublime. 10/10, would spill again."

Business

Perpendicular Grand Hotel Awarded 'Most Structurally Ambiguous' Inn of the Year

The Perpendicular Grand on Titan, known for its rotating gravitational fields and hallways that occasionally lead back to Tuesday, has won the coveted "Escher Award" for architectural improbability.

Opinion

The Ground is a Crutch, People

By Barnaby 'Bix' Whiskerton: For too long we have let ourselves be coddled by the oppressive predictability of a solid surface. It's time we, as a society, learned to float on our own four paws. The future is up. Or sideways. The point is, it isn't *down*.

Travel Advisory

High-Velocity Tumbleweeds Reported in Martian Lounges

Travelers are advised that low-G agricultural experiments have resulted in rogue, high-velocity tumbleweeds within the main concourse of Olympus Mons Spaceport. Please secure your valuables and bar snacks.

An official statement from airport management reads: "We are aware of the tumbleweed situation and are looking into solutions that do not involve a giant, space-faring cat."
